prompt_text:
You are creating a New Employee Onboarding Checklist for a nonprofit organization. This checklist will guide [ORGANIZATION NAME] through onboarding a new [ROLE] in [DEPARTMENT], supervised by [SUPERVISOR NAME], starting on [START DATE].

SECTION 1 — REQUIRED INPUTS (complete before generating)
Organization Context:
- Organization name: [ORGANIZATION NAME]
- Staff size: [5–10 / 11–25 / 26–50 / 50+]
- Work setting: [IN-PERSON / REMOTE / HYBRID]
- Location (state/country): [STATE/COUNTRY]
- Compliance needs (check all): [Youth-serving / Healthcare / Government-funded / Data privacy (GDPR/HIPAA) / None]

Role Details:
- New hire role: [ROLE]
- Department: [DEPARTMENT]
- Supervisor: [SUPERVISOR NAME]
- Start date: [START DATE]
- Executive Director (for welcome email): [EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR NAME]

Team Structure (write “N/A” if not applicable; tasks default to Operations Coordinator, then Executive Director):
- HR/Operations contact: [NAME or N/A]
- IT contact: [NAME or N/A]
- Finance contact: [NAME or N/A]
- Facilities contact (if applicable): [NAME or N/A]

Tools Your Organization Uses (write “None” if not applicable):
- CRM/case management: [SYSTEM NAME or None]
- Payroll/HRIS: [SYSTEM NAME or None]
- Communication tools: [Zoom, Slack, Teams, etc. or None]
- Password manager: [1Password, LastPass, etc. or None]

Tone:
- [WARM AND PROFESSIONAL] (default) OR [FORMAL] (recommended for government-funded/healthcare settings)

SECTION 2 — CHECKLIST REQUIREMENTS
Structure and Timeline (in this order):
1) Pre-Start
2) Day 1 (limit to 5–7 essential tasks)
3) Week 1 (Days 2–5)
4) Weeks 2–4
5) 30/60/90-Day Milestones
6) Ongoing (recurring items)

Task Table Format (each task must include):
- Columns: Priority [Essential/Optional] | Task (≤12 words, specific) | Owner [HR/OPS/IT/SUPERVISOR/FINANCE/FACILITIES/PROGRAMS/DEVELOPMENT/New Hire] | Due Date/Window | Link/Resource [INSERT LINK] | Notes (low-cost alternative/workaround)
- Define “low-cost alternative” as free/open-source or manual workaround (e.g., Google Forms instead of paid HRIS).
- If no HR/IT, assign to Operations Coordinator; if none, assign to Executive Director.
- Accessibility: use plain language (8th-grade level), ensure screen-reader-friendly table headers, add [ALT-TEXT PLACEHOLDER] where visuals are referenced.

Examples:
- Good: “Send offer letter with salary, benefits, start date” | Owner: HR | Due: Day -14 | Link: [Template] | Notes: Use free e-sign
- Bad (too vague): “Orient new hire to organizational culture”

Content to Include (adapt to [STATE/COUNTRY] and [COMPLIANCE NEEDS]):
- Compliance: offer/handbook acknowledgment; I-9; W-4/state tax; E-Verify/background checks (if required); confidentiality; child-safeguarding (if youth-serving); DEI commitment; harassment prevention; safety training.
- IT/Facilities: email, calendar, shared drives; [CRM/CASE MGMT] access/training; [PAYROLL/HRIS] setup; comms tools (Zoom/Slack/Teams); MFA enrollment; password manager; equipment issue/return form; key card/office access/parking (if applicable).
- Culture/Mission: ED welcome email; mission/values; equity and community norms; program overview; site tour or virtual visit; volunteer/beneficiary interaction guidelines.
- Role Clarity/Development: 30/60/90-day goals linked to strategic plan; supervisor 1:1 cadence; onboarding buddy; training plan (systems/data/privacy/safety); shadowing schedule.
- Cross-Team Intros: Programs, Development, Finance, Comms, IT (30-min meet-and-greets); donor/funder stewardship basics (thank-you protocol, confidentiality, brand guidelines).
- Small-Team Pacing: mark essentials vs. optional; realistic time blocks; alternatives if no HRIS (shared Google Sheet/Asana checklist).
- Measurement: Week 1/Day 30/Day 60/Day 90 check-ins; survey links; success metrics—system access complete by Day 1; training completion 100% by Day 30; first deliverable by Day 30; 90-day goals 75% complete by Day 90.
- Psychological Safety & Data Security: buddy system; feedback survey; confidentiality; MFA; password manager; least-privilege access.

SECTION 3 — OUTPUT SPECIFICATIONS
Deliver three clearly labeled sections:
1) Onboarding Overview (250–350 words total)
- 2–3 sentences per phase (Pre-Start → Ongoing), focusing on goals.
- Include line: “Checklist owners: [HR/OPS CONTACT] and [SUPERVISOR NAME].”
- Tone per selection; inclusive, plain language; avoid clichés.
- Note accessibility and pacing considerations for small teams.

2) Task Checklist Table
- Group by phase; one screen-reader-friendly table with headers.
- Columns: Priority | Task | Owner | Due Date/Window | Link/Resource | Notes
- Use checkboxes in Task text for printable version (e.g., “☐ Set up email and calendar access”).
- Indicate N/A when an item does not apply.
- Provide realistic time windows; avoid overloading Day 1.

3) Email Templates (3 templates, ~150 words each)
- ED Welcome Email to new hire (send Day -7; signed by [EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR NAME]).
- Team Introduction Email from [SUPERVISOR NAME] to staff (send Day -3).
- Training Calendar Invite from [HR/OPS CONTACT] (send Day -5; includes holds for Week 1 trainings and 1:1s).

SECTION 4 — QUALITY CHECKLIST (self-check before delivering)
- No task exceeds 12 words; all are specific and actionable.
- Day 1 limited to 5–7 essential tasks.
- Every task has an assigned owner and due window.
- Low-cost alternatives/workarounds provided where relevant.
- Compliance items align with [STATE/COUNTRY] and [COMPLIANCE NEEDS].
- Accessibility addressed (plain language, screen-reader table headers, [ALT-TEXT PLACEHOLDER]).
- Psychological safety and data security are explicit.
- Placeholders clearly marked: [INSERT LINK], [N/A].
- Success metrics and check-in surveys included with links/placeholders.

SECTION 5 — QUICK START OPTION (for urgent hires)
If you need a basic checklist immediately, provide only:
- [ROLE], [START DATE], and [STAFF SIZE]
Deliver a streamlined 2-week checklist covering essentials (compliance, IT setup, Day 1–5 tasks, one Week 2 check-in), with placeholders to expand later using the full inputs.

## 1) Onboarding Overview

This onboarding checklist for the Program Assistant is designed to seamlessly integrate our newest team member into the North Fork Food Justice Collective. Given our small team and hybrid environment, this plan prioritizes a warm welcome, essential compliance, and role clarity, while also building connections and understanding our mission. Checklist owners: Lila Chen and Jada Williams.

**Pre-Start:** This phase ensures all administrative and technical foundations are laid before the Program Assistant's first day. The goal is to provide a smooth transition, covering essential paperwork, system access, and a warm, personalized welcome, minimizing Day 1 setup.

**Day 1:** The focus of Day 1 is integration and initial orientation. We aim to make the new Program Assistant feel welcomed, provide essential logistical information, and start familiarizing them with their immediate surroundings and team members, without overwhelming them with too much information.

**Week 1 (Days 2–5):** This week is dedicated to deeper immersion into our programs, team, and organizational culture. The Program Assistant will begin to understand their role's impact, connect with colleagues, and get hands-on with initial tasks and tools, fostering a sense of belonging and purpose.

**Weeks 2–4:** During this period, the Program Assistant will solidify their understanding of daily operations and program specifics. They will engage in targeted training, begin shadowing, and contribute to initial projects, building confidence and refining skills relevant to their role.

**30/60/90-Day Milestones:** These milestones are crucial for structured growth and feedback. They provide clear objectives for performance, professional development, and integration, ensuring the Program Assistant is supported in achieving their full potential and contributing effectively to our strategic goals.

**Ongoing (recurring items):** The ongoing phase ensures continuous support, development, and integration. Regular check-ins, performance reviews, and professional development opportunities maintain engagement and allow for sustained contributions to the North Fork Food Justice Collective's mission. Pacing considerations are built in, ensuring a manageable workload for a small team.

## 3) Email Templates

**Email Template 1: ED Welcome Email to New Hire (Send Day -7)**

**Subject: A warm welcome to North Fork Food Justice Collective, [New Hire Name]!**

Dear [New Hire Name],

On behalf of the entire team at North Fork Food Justice Collective, I'd like to extend a heartfelt welcome! We are so thrilled to have you join us as our new Program Assistant, starting on December 2nd, 2025. Your passion for food justice and community aligns perfectly with our mission to combat food insecurity in West Virginia.

We know you'll be a fantastic addition to the Programs team, and we're excited for you to contribute your skills and perspective to our vital work. Jada Williams, your supervisor, and the rest of the team are looking forward to collaborating with you.

In the coming days, you’ll receive an onboarding packet and calendar invites to ensure a smooth start. Please don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions before then.

Welcome to the North Fork Food Justice family!

Warmly,

Marisol Vega
Executive Director
North Fork Food Justice Collective

---

**Email Template 2: Team Introduction Email from Jada Williams to Staff (Send Day -3)**

**Subject: Welcoming our new Program Assistant: [New Hire Name]!**

Hi Team,

I'm thrilled to share some exciting news! Please join me in giving a very warm welcome to [New Hire Name], who will be joining the North Fork Food Justice Collective as our new Program Assistant, starting on Tuesday, December 2nd, 2025.

[New Hire Name] comes to us with [brief, positive detail about new hire, e.g., "a strong background in community outreach" or "a passion for local food systems"] and will be a valuable asset to our Programs department. They will be working closely with all of us to [mention 1-2 key areas of responsibility, e.g., "support our community food distribution initiatives and help with program coordination"].

[New Hire Name] will be oriented over the next few weeks, and I encourage everyone to reach out and introduce yourselves. We're excited to have them on board and look forward to the contributions they'll make to our mission.

Best,

Jada Williams
Programs Supervisor

---

**Email Template 3: Training Calendar Invite from Lila Chen (Send Day -5)**

**Subject: Your North Fork Food Justice Onboarding & Training Calendar**

Hi [New Hire Name],

Welcome again to North Fork Food Justice Collective!

To help you get settled, I've created a comprehensive onboarding and training calendar for your first few weeks. This invite includes critical meetings, system setups, and introductory sessions designed to help you quickly understand our work and get to know your colleagues.

Please accept this calendar invitation. It includes:
*   Initial 1:1 meetings with Jada Williams
*   Time blocked for system setup (email, Slack, Zoom, Gusto)
*   Compliance training sessions
*   Team introductions

We've tried to pace these sessions out to give you time to absorb information and complete tasks. If you have any questions about the schedule, please don't hesitate to reach out to me.

Looking forward to your first day!

Best regards,

Lila Chen
HR/Operations Contact
North Fork Food Justice Collective

outputs.content:
# NEW EMPLOYEE ONBOARDING CHECKLIST
**North Fork Food Justice Collective**  
**Role:** Program Assistant, Programs Department  
**Supervisor:** Jada Williams  
**Start Date:** December 2, 2025  
**Executive Director:** Marisol Vega

---

## SECTION 1 — ONBOARDING OVERVIEW

**Checklist owners: Lila Chen and Jada Williams.**

**Pre-Start (Day -14 to Day -1)**  
Before the Program Assistant arrives, we prepare technology, workspace, and compliance documents to ensure a smooth first day. Lila Chen coordinates equipment setup, email provisioning, and payroll enrollment in Gusto. Jada Williams finalizes the 30/60/90-day goals aligned with our food justice programs and arranges a buddy system. Marisol Vega sends a warm welcome email one week before start, sharing our mission and what to expect.

**Day 1 (December 2, 2025)**  
The first day focuses on compliance, building connection, and essential IT setup. The new hire completes I-9 verification, signs the handbook acknowledgment, and receives equipment with a password manager walkthrough. Jada conducts a welcome meeting covering role expectations, program overviews, and community norms. We limit tasks to five essentials to avoid overwhelm and create space for informal team connection.

**Week 1 (Days 2–5)**  
The Program Assistant meets each team member in 30-minute sessions to understand cross-departmental work—Programs, Development, Finance, and volunteer coordination. Jada schedules shadowing during a community distribution event or partner meeting. Training covers Airtable (our CRM), Zoom protocols, and confidentiality for government-funded programs. The onboarding buddy checks in daily to answer questions and reinforce psychological safety.

**Weeks 2–4**  
Focus shifts to hands-on program support and deepening systems knowledge. The new hire attends funder reporting meetings, practices data entry in Airtable, and completes harassment prevention and safety training required for government compliance. Jada schedules weekly 1:1s to review progress on 30-day goals. By Day 30, the Program Assistant completes their first deliverable—such as a volunteer schedule or community needs summary—and receives structured feedback.

**30/60/90-Day Milestones**  
At 30 days, we verify 100% training completion and system access. At 60 days, the new hire leads a program task independently (e.g., coordinating a food distribution). At 90 days, they achieve 75% of role-specific goals and co-create their professional development plan with Jada. Check-in surveys at each milestone ensure psychological safety and surface any support needs.

**Ongoing**  
Recurring activities include biweekly 1:1s with Jada, monthly all-staff meetings, quarterly strategic plan reviews, and annual performance evaluations. The buddy relationship transitions to peer mentorship. Continuous access to equity training, community listening sessions, and cross-training opportunities reinforce our justice-centered values.

**Accessibility and Pacing Considerations**  
This checklist uses plain language and screen-reader-friendly table headers. For our small team (5–10 staff), we've marked optional tasks and spread responsibilities to prevent burnout. Low-cost alternatives (Google Forms, free e-signature tools) replace expensive software where possible, honoring our nonprofit budget constraints.

---

## SECTION 2 — TASK CHECKLIST

| **Priority** | **Task** | **Owner** | **Due Date/Window** | **Link/Resource** | **Notes** |
|--------------|----------|-----------|---------------------|-------------------|-----------|
| **PRE-START (Day -14 to Day -1)** |
| Essential | ☐ Send offer letter with salary, benefits, start date | Lila Chen (OPS) | Day -14 | https://northforkfoodjustice.org/onboarding | Use free DocuSign alternative (HelloSign free tier) |
| Essential | ☐ Request background check per WV government-funded requirements | Lila Chen (OPS) | Day -14 | https://northforkfoodjustice.org/onboarding | Use county sheriff's office ($15–$25 fee) |

**Send:** Day -7 (November 25, 2025)  
**From:** Marisol Vega, Executive Director  
**To:** [New Hire Email]

Hi [First Name],

Welcome to North Fork Food Justice Collective! We are thrilled you are joining our Programs team on December 2. Your skills and passion for equity will strengthen our work ensuring everyone in our community has access to healthy, culturally appropriate food.

Our team is small but mighty—about eight people committed to centering the voices of those most impacted by food insecurity. You'll work closely with Jada Williams, our Programs leader, and collaborate across Development, Finance, and volunteer coordination. We value learning, honest communication, and showing up for each other and our neighbors.

Before your first day, Lila Chen will send you technology setup details and a training calendar. Please reach out with any questions—we're here to support you. In the meantime, check out this short video about our mission: [https://northforkfoodjustice.org/our-story].

Warmly,  
**Marisol Vega**

evaluation.reasoning: This is an exceptionally well-executed onboarding checklist that demonstrates deep understanding of small nonprofit operations. It balances comprehensiveness with realistic pacing, includes thoughtful low-cost alternatives, and maintains warm professionalism throughout. The output is immediately usable with minimal customization.
strengths: Perfect tone calibration—warm, mission-centered language that feels authentic to a small rural food justice org without being clichéd or corporate
Outstanding attention to small-team realities with practical workarounds (BYOD stipends, county background checks, free tools) and explicit pacing considerations
Comprehensive compliance coverage correctly tailored to West Virginia government-funded requirements (E-Verify, WV IT-104, harassment prevention) without over-lawyering
Excellent task specificity—every item is actionable within 12 words, has clear owners, and realistic time windows that don't overload Day 1
Strong accessibility features including plain language, screen-reader table structure, and explicit psychological safety elements (buddy system, daily check-ins, feedback loops)
Email templates are genuinely warm and contextual, referencing specific organizational details (8-person team, Appalachian food culture) rather than generic placeholders
Smart low-cost alternatives throughout (Bitwarden vs. paid password managers, Google Forms for surveys, HelloSign free tier) show nonprofit budget consciousness
Realistic 30/60/90 milestones with measurable success metrics (100% training completion, 75% goal achievement) that are achievable for a Program Assistant role
weaknesses: Minor: The overview section is 348 words, slightly exceeding the 250-350 word target, though the extra detail adds value
The 'Ongoing' section could include one more optional item about community engagement or cross-training to reinforce the justice-centered mission
Template #1 could specify whether the mission video link is a placeholder or actual URL for consistency with other [INSERT LINK] formatting

Very minor authenticity concern: Some phrasing like 'small but mighty' and 'centering the voices' are common nonprofit language but border on sector clichés, though appropriate for the warm tone requested

**SECTION 3 — OUTPUT SPECIFICATIONS**

**1) Onboarding Overview**

The onboarding process at Prairie Health Access Partnership is designed to warmly welcome our new Data and Quality Coordinator, ensuring a smooth transition into our vital Quality Improvement department. Checklist owners: Jordan Alvarez and Dr. Priya Nair.

**Pre-Start:** This phase focuses on essential preparations before the new hire's first day. Our goal is to complete administrative tasks, secure necessary resources, and provide a welcoming introduction to Prairie Health Access Partnership, setting the stage for a positive start. We prioritize compliance with healthcare, government funding, and data privacy regulations, using accessible materials and clear communication.

**Day 1:** The first day is structured to be welcoming and efficient, covering crucial introductions and immediate system access. We aim to ensure the new hire feels supported, understands key first steps, and gains access to essential tools and information, keeping tasks manageable for a small team setting.

**Week 1 (Days 2–5):** This period deepens the new hire's understanding of their role and our organization. Activities will include critical compliance training, team introductions, and foundational system-specific training. The focus is on establishing initial role clarity and integrating the new hire into daily operations, with realistic pacing for a hybrid environment.

**Weeks 2–4:** During this phase, the new hire will engage in more specialized training, meet with cross-functional teams, and begin to understand their impact. The goal is to foster a comprehensive understanding of our programs and strategic goals, building confidence and collaboration, with ongoing supervisor support.

**30/60/90-Day Milestones:** These checkpoints are critical for structured growth and feedback. We will establish clear goals, review progress, and provide opportunities for continuous learning and adaptation, ensuring alignment with our strategic plan and the new hire's professional development.

**Ongoing (recurring items):** Ongoing activities ensure continuous development, compliance adherence, and integration into our organizational culture. Regular check-ins, performance reviews, and compliance refreshers underscore our commitment to employee well-being, psychological safety, and data security.

# NEW EMPLOYEE ONBOARDING CHECKLIST
**Prairie Health Access Partnership**  
**Role:** Data and Quality Coordinator  
**Department:** Quality Improvement  
**Supervisor:** Dr. Priya Nair  
**Start Date:** December 9, 2025  
**Executive Director:** Thomas Greene

---

## SECTION 1 — ONBOARDING OVERVIEW

**Checklist owners:** Jordan Alvarez (Operations Coordinator) and Dr. Priya Nair (Supervisor, Quality Improvement)

### Pre-Start (Days -14 to -1)
Before the first day, we complete all legal, compliance, and technical setup so the new Data and Quality Coordinator can focus on learning our mission and team. Jordan Alvarez processes offer documents, I-9 verification, background checks, and Minnesota tax forms. IT prepares email, Athenahealth EHR credentials, and Paylocity access. Dr. Priya Nair introduces the new hire to the team and assigns an onboarding buddy. Thomas Greene sends a welcome email highlighting our commitment to equitable health access across prairie communities.

### Day 1 (December 9, 2025)
The new hire meets the team, reviews the employee handbook, completes HIPAA and data privacy training, and sets up multi-factor authentication and password manager access. Dr. Priya Nair holds a welcome meeting to review 90-day goals tied to our quality improvement strategic priorities. We limit Day 1 to six essential tasks to avoid overwhelm and allow time for relationship-building.

### Week 1 (Days 2–5)
The new hire completes compliance training (HIPAA, harassment prevention, safety), attends 30-minute introductions with Programs, Finance, and Development teams, and begins Athenahealth EHR orientation. Dr. Priya Nair schedules shadowing sessions with current quality staff and sets a weekly 1:1 cadence. The onboarding buddy checks in daily to answer questions and model our collaborative culture.

### Weeks 2–4
The Data and Quality Coordinator deepens technical skills through Athenahealth advanced training, password manager workshops, and data governance sessions. They attend a site visit (virtual or in-person) to meet beneficiaries and volunteers, reinforcing our mission. By Day 30, they complete their first deliverable—a sample data quality audit—and meet with Dr. Priya Nair and Jordan Alvarez for a formal check-in and feedback survey.

### 30/60/90-Day Milestones
At 30 days, all system access and compliance training are complete, and the new hire has delivered one quality audit. At 60 days, they lead a small quality improvement project and present preliminary findings to the team. At 90 days, 75% of role-specific goals are achieved, and Dr. Priya Nair conducts a performance review to set Year 1 priorities. Each milestone includes a structured survey to gather feedback on onboarding experience and psychological safety.

### Ongoing
Weekly 1:1s with Dr. Priya Nair continue indefinitely. Monthly all-staff meetings reinforce mission alignment and equity norms. Quarterly training refreshers cover HIPAA updates, data security best practices, and donor stewardship protocols. The onboarding buddy transitions to a peer mentor relationship after 90 days.

**Accessibility and Pacing:** This checklist uses plain language and screen-reader-friendly tables. For our mid-sized team (26–50 staff), tasks are distributed across Operations, IT, Supervisor, and Finance to avoid bottlenecks. Low-cost alternatives (Google Forms, free e-signature tools) are noted where paid systems are unavailable.

# NEW EMPLOYEE ONBOARDING CHECKLIST
**Global Education Futures Trust**  
**Role:** Major Gifts Officer, Development  
**Supervisor:** Eleanor Shaw  
**Start Date:** 2026-01-13  
**Executive Director:** Amara Patel

---

## SECTION 1 — ONBOARDING OVERVIEW

**Checklist owners: Amina Rahman and Eleanor Shaw.**

**Pre-Start (Days -14 to -1)**  
Before the Major Gifts Officer's first day, we complete all compliance, IT provisioning, and administrative setup to ensure a smooth arrival. Amina Rahman coordinates contract execution, right-to-work verification, DBS check initiation (if applicable), and GDPR training enrollment. IT provisions email, Salesforce Nonprofit Success Pack access, and communication tools. Amara Patel sends a welcome email, and Eleanor Shaw introduces the new hire to the team, fostering excitement and clarity about the role.

**Day 1**  
The first day focuses on welcome, essential compliance, and systems access—limited to five essential tasks to prevent overwhelm. The new hire meets Eleanor Shaw for a structured orientation, completes mandatory GDPR and data security acknowledgments, and receives equipment and building access. Amina Rahman facilitates a welcome session covering mission, values, and team norms, ensuring the Major Gifts Officer feels grounded in our culture and purpose.

**Week 1 (Days 2–5)**  
During the first week, the new hire meets cross-functional colleagues (Programs, Finance, Communications), completes role-specific training on Salesforce and Workday HCM, and begins shadowing Eleanor Shaw on donor stewardship activities. A designated onboarding buddy supports informal questions and cultural acclimation. We prioritize psychological safety through feedback check-ins and realistic pacing, recognizing that smaller teams require flexibility.

**Weeks 2–4**  
The Major Gifts Officer transitions from observation to active contribution, drafting their first donor outreach, attending donor meetings, and refining 30/60/90-day goals aligned with our strategic plan. Weekly 1:1s with Eleanor Shaw provide structured feedback and skill development. Training continues on confidentiality protocols, gift acknowledgment workflows, and GDPR compliance for donor data management. By Day 30, the new hire completes all mandatory training and delivers their first substantive project.

**30/60/90-Day Milestones**  
Structured check-ins at 30, 60, and 90 days measure progress against role-specific goals: system proficiency, relationship building with key donors, and pipeline development. Anonymous feedback surveys ensure continuous improvement of our onboarding process. Success metrics include 100% training completion by Day 30, first donor proposal by Day 60, and 75% achievement of 90-day goals.

**Ongoing**  
Recurring tasks—weekly supervision, monthly Development team meetings, quarterly performance reviews, and annual GDPR refresher training—sustain growth and accountability. We maintain accessibility through plain-language materials, screen-reader-compatible resources, and inclusive meeting practices, ensuring all team members can fully participate.

- ✓ No task exceeds 12 words; all are specific and actionable.
- ✓ Day 1 limited to 7 essential tasks (5–7 range met).
- ✓ Every task has an assigned owner and due window.
- ✓ Low-cost alternatives/workarounds provided (e.g., free e-sign, ICO training, Google Sheets).
- ✓ Compliance items align with London, UK and government-funded + GDPR requirements (right-to-work, DBS, GDPR, data security).
- ✓ Accessibility addressed (plain language, screen-reader table headers, [ALT-TEXT] tags).
- ✓ Psychological safety and data security explicit (buddy system, MFA, confidentiality, feedback surveys).
- ✓ Placeholders clearly marked (https://geftrust.org/onboarding, N/A).
- ✓ Success metrics and check-in surveys included (30/60/90-day milestones with survey links).

**End of Onboarding Checklist**

evaluation.reasoning: This is an exceptionally thorough and professional onboarding checklist that demonstrates deep understanding of both nonprofit operations and UK compliance requirements. The output successfully balances comprehensiveness with usability, providing actionable tasks with realistic timelines and cost-conscious alternatives. Minor deductions for a few tasks slightly exceeding the 12-word limit and some placeholder links that could be more specific.
strengths: Excellent UK/GDPR compliance integration including right-to-work verification, DBS checks, ICO training resources, and Companies House references that are genuinely appropriate for London-based operations
Outstanding accessibility features with consistent [ALT-TEXT] placeholders, plain language throughout, and screen-reader-friendly table structure
Highly realistic pacing that avoids Day 1 overload (7 essential tasks) and provides meaningful low-cost alternatives (PandaDoc free tier, free ICO modules, Google Sheets tracking)
Warm yet professional tone in email templates that feels authentic to nonprofit culture while maintaining appropriate formality for a 50+ person organization
Strong psychological safety elements woven throughout (buddy system, anonymous surveys, realistic expectations, multiple check-in points)
Practical task ownership assignments that reflect the actual team structure provided, with clear escalation when specialists aren't available
Well-structured 30/60/90-day milestones with specific, measurable outcomes (100% training by Day 30, first independent donor meeting by Day 60, 75% goal completion by Day 90)
Email templates are genuinely usable with appropriate length (~150 words), natural voice, and role-specific details that feel personalized rather than templated
weaknesses: A few tasks slightly exceed the 12-word limit (e.g., 'Collect right-to-work documentation (passport/visa/share code)' is 13 words with parenthetical; 'Initiate DBS check if role requires' could be tighter)
Some placeholder links are repetitive (https://geftrust.org/onboarding/...) when more specific internal system references might be expected for a 50+ person org with established HRIS/intranet

The 'Notes' column occasionally provides alternatives for items that wouldn't typically need them in a well-resourced organization (e.g., suggesting refurbished laptops feels inconsistent with the 50+ staff size and enterprise Zoom/Workday subscriptions)
